pros: Great work experience Very good management structure Generous PTO

pros: Great work life balance. Flexible hours.

pros: Very flexible, decent bonuses (10% of base salary), able to work independently.

pros: Good environment and people on team

job_title: Health Care Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: The work is interesting, and it is great to see that the work you do is actually making a difference.
cons: Unfortunately, your reward for doing well, is taking on more work outside of your job description, without extra compensation. When I felt overwhelmed, I was told that, "doing well at the job is rewarded with more work." When I asked if extra compensation will be added for the extra roles I play outside of my job description, I was told, "No, not for the extra work you will be doing while in the role of a Health Care Analyst." I really do enjoy my job, but it has come to the point where I want to search for other jobs that pay what I know I deserve.

review_title: NCQA is a Great Place to Work!

review_title: Great mission; still trying to stay relevant
pros: Benefits, people you work with
cons: Lots of changes and tons of work on some teams along with intense pressure and unrealistic expectations.

pros: Flexibility in work location, benefits, managers are understanding.
cons: Overallocation of time, unrealistic expectations for workload.

pros: Interesting work, passionate coworkers, work-from home options, bonus, paid-time off
cons:
Ability and workload varies significantly between departments even though this is not accounted for in compensation. Mid-level capable staff gets dumped on and working around the clock expected. There are consistently unrealistic timelines and senior leadership only cares about the bottom line. NCQA used to be a more mission driven organization but with the recent internal issues (see posts below) that organization has changed significantly. Most higher level staff do not trust mid-level staff to produce materials and there are endless review cycles up the chain of command. Staff are also discouraged from having opinions. It is all about executing what senior level staff think without question. Errors are not tolerated. While there are opportunities to be promoted, they come with no training on management and the organization suffers as a result. Certain senior-level staff just coast by since they have been at NCQA for over 6 years before the PCMH profit bubble. There is no accountability on supervisors and while you will receive a performance review with a subjective rating system there is NO opportunity to evaluate your supervisors. 

Staff morale is at the lowest it has been and turnover is rampant throughout all levels of the organization. Even the recent great place to work initiatives have been poorly attended by staff. I do not recommend joining this depressing organization.

pros: NCQA is a vibrant place to work, the people are energetic and diverse, and the company is trying to use creative ways to encourage work/life balance such as offering very progressive flex schedules and telecommuting arrangements. The office is also well located and is a physically comfortable place to work.
cons:
It is not evident that any real thought is put into comprehensive and company-wide project management therefore 55 to 65 hour work weeks are the norm at NCQA and anything less puts you behind on your unending and crushing workload. Sadly, falling behind inspires nothing but contempt from management, who themselves are clocking in their 80th hour for the week.

Unfortunately all the posters depicting the virtues of respect, trust, and flexibility accomplish absolutely nothing other than to rub salt in the wounds of passersby, from certain departments, who are retreating to their desk after their third beating of the day. I'm from one of those departments, but to be fair, my direct supervisor usually acknowledges good work and constructively responds to less than stellar performance, even when their manager treats them like garbage.

Aside from workload issues, interactions with upper management in some departments can be downright ugly. They all have their own agendas and their own opinions on everything from the interpretation of company policy to the exact order of presentation slides. Most people are allocated to several high-profile projects which involve multiple members of upper management, so a lot of their time is spent appeasing multiple opinions to get work done.

job_title: Product Development Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: Love the company and the mission
cons: no cons, overall a great company to work for.

cons: None that I can think of right now

review_title: Don't stay too long if you want to advance in your career
pros: The company has great benefits, flexible work schedule, you are entrusted with new projects and learn a lot, The atmosphere is very much like a family, staff treats each other very nice.  Upper Management is very approachable
cons: If you do not work in the research or health care track there is not much potential for career growth. You are entrusted with increasing responsibility and learn a lot along the way without equivalent increase in compensation and without advancing to higher position even after getting a high level degree in your field of work. A degree does not help, unless you are in healthcare or research. Internal promotion seems almost impossible. Getting a degree in your field does not help, unless you are working in the health care or research departments. If you are ambitious and want to grow in your career unfortunately this is not the place to be. If you are fine with staying where you are career-wise and position-wise and work with nice people, this could be a good place for you to work.

pros:
1. Driven coworkers who care about the mission
2. High standards of work 
3. Flexible scheduling options and telework 
4. Metro accessible
5. Great benefits at one point
cons:
Overall, I felt like I got the bait and switch. My Interview process and HR orientation was great and made me really excited about working here... And then as soon as I started working, everything has gone down hill and quickly ever since.

1. Many people are treated unfairly 
2. Horrible management experience. I consider myself to be a very well-adjusted person and I was brought to tears by some of the communication I received from my manager.
3. No work life balance; my team on average works 50-60 hours a week with no recognition as it was considered the norm 
4. Leadership team is condescending and out of touch
5. So many promises made but nothing ever changes
6. Work "fun" events are only tailored to certain people and feel really forced.

pros: Dedicated employees, job stability, extra curricular activities, annual incentive program, opportunity to travel all around the country, good health insurance and educational assistance benefits..
cons: Always under staffed, high stress, high pressure, low salaries for non leadership team, high turnover, lack oft recognition and positive reinforcement, meager pay raises, no raises in the last year.  You can't tell that this is a not for profit company because of huge emphasis on increasing revenues by any means necessary.  Ethical concerns about excepting money from "sponsors" who undergo accreditation and certification surveys.  Long hours, poor boundaries inability to really take time off due to workloads and expectations.

review_title: Great benefits, great team, not appreciated at company
pros: Great benefits - generous PTO and # of paid holidays, great flexibility to work from home or go full-time remote. The team is great - fun people who are very smart, helpful, and capable.
cons: Other teams bully and disrespect the data scientists. It is extremely frustrating. Many people punch downward and kiss up to the people above them.  There are of course some wonderful people there, but the bad ones spoil the experience. They hire people for their technical skills but there is little opportunity to use or grow them, the higher your position is. You can achieve a work-life balance but you have to fight hard for it and make some people angry.

review_title: Good place to start a career, but limited growth
pros:
- Competitive pay
- Excellent benefits
- Strives to be a great place to work
- Excellent facility
cons:
- Siloed departments leads to a lack of communication and multiple departments doing the same work
- Not all departments respected/resourced equally
- Not all employees rewarded equally
- Some departments are overworked and stretched thin, while others are overstaffed
- Manual processes and outdated tech badly need updating
- Mild interest in acknowledging and solving above problems

review_title: A decent place to work that has the potential to be great
pros: Employees are hard working and are passionate about NCQA's mission.  The company is striving to become a "great place to work".  The offices are well maintained and there is a pleasant atmosphere.  Every employee is eligible for an annual incentive which seems unique for a non-profit.
cons: NCQA has some outdated internal policies and management.  Baby boomer management struggles to embrace the needs of a changing millennial workforce.  There is also a widespread intolerance for error and downward communication can at times be sharp/disrespectful.

review_title: NCQA is the Best Employer I've Worked For!
job_title: Senior Operations Engineer, Accreditation in Washington, DC
pros:
In my 23 years in the workforce, I have never worked for an organization like this one. Opportunities for advancement continue as NCQA evolves and expands. For example, I have been promoted twice during my five-year tenure at NCQA, and many of my talented colleagues have also been promoted. Our Great Place to Work (GPTW) committee makes this place special. The cohesive workplace culture fosters engagement and comradery. Our executive leadership team walks the walk in strategy, integrity, transparency, accountability, vision, and interpersonal communication. They are approachable and appreciate hearing from staff, which cultivates a comfortable and high-performing work environment. They genuinely value our diverse NCQA family. 

From flexible schedules to work-from-home options, work-life balance is not just an idea at NCQA. We live it and breathe it while committing ourselves to important work each day. The health insurance benefits are top notch! In fact, I have never in my life had such great health insurance. Leadership and GPTW regularly host employee events and activities because socializing, laughter, and teambuilding are essential to our culture. Our HR team goes above and beyond in creating a safe, inclusive, and empowered workplace. HR provides abundant opportunities and resources for talent development and education. Building knowledge, applying passion, and gaining experience are all welcome here. Last but not least, annual merits and bonuses are a major highlight of the quality work we do.  If you enjoy surrounding yourself with brilliant, compassionate, and fun individuals, then you will thrive here, especially if you are committed to improving the quality of healthcare.
cons: As with any employer and in any fast-paced work environment, you must be good with managing your time between many meetings, re-prioritizing based on business needs, and juggling many projects/tasks/emails. They have resources to help you with this, if needed. Sometimes tasks are assigned to you late or at the last minute when business needs change, but they have drastically improved in this area. Adaptation is key! Quality is a journey and not a destination, and I give NCQA credit for making great progress with strategic planning and transparency.  Again with any employer, you will always have personalities of all kinds to work with and for. However, HR does an amazing job supporting staff and  facilitating constructive change across individuals, teams, and departments. We work hard and smart at NCQA. I enjoy the work while constantly learning and challenging myself. The cons are truly minimal, especially with the abundant benefits and resources available to us.  No workplace is 100% perfect, but NCQA is as close to perfection as realistically possible.

pros: Organization had an excellent mission and interesting work.
cons: The pace in certain departments was extremely challenging.  Senior management was constantly seeking new opportunities with respect to grants, research, and projects, which is a good thing.  However, trying to apportion new and additional work across an already over-taxed staff was frustrating and challenging.  Reviewing the organization's annual workplace survey was also an interesting experience:  the closer staff was to the executive, the more disaffected they seemed to be.

review_title: Really a Great Place to Work Especially if for Families

review_title: Not so much a Great Place to Work
pros: Flexible scheduling and telework are available but only for certain positions and departments. Some of the social events are nicely done.
cons: Not as transparent as they claim to be. And an open door policy doesn't apply to all leadership and management which is disappointing.

pros: People are fantastic and talented. The recruiting at ncqa is out of this world. They truly hire the best of the best. Benefits compensation are good
cons: The executive team is out of touch and has been for many years. They are biased, crass, ungrateful for all the work performed by employees. Speaking of work, they actually work people to death and sadly mostly with minutia and detail work. They do not cultivate people's strengths and encourage their people to use their skills and lead the way. This applies to everyone below the executives. It doesn't matter what title you have, you are relegated to working on minute details repeatedly. They do not show gratitude for the hard work. They also make terrible decisions letting superior talent leave the company over the past two years due to their atrocious management. They have literally driven people off the edge and kill the passion in people. Many people besides the ones who have already left are looking for another job
